content.question: A psychologist has just developed a new test that he hopes will be a good measure of intelligence. The psychologist got fellow content experts to look at the questions to confirm that they are the types of puzzles and problems that would provide an intellectual challenge and give insight into someoneâ€™s intellectual abilities. Unfortunately, when he distributes the test to a classroom of college students, it does not appear to perform similarly to existing measures of intelligence. The test does not predict student GPAs and in fact is better at predicting performance on a measure of anxiety than intelligence. Which of the following characteristics does the new intelligence test possess?

choices.label: Split-half reliability, because the odd items had the same rates of accuracy as the even items.
Test-retest reliability, because the students performed the same each time they took the test.
Construct validity, because the psychologist has demonstrated that the test measures what it is intended to measure.
Predictive validity, because the test predicts future academic performance.

content.answer: Construct validity, because the psychologist has demonstrated that the test measures what it is intended to measure.
